text: I'll be finishing up this chapter this evening, verses 22 through 34. And this is our 55th lesson through the book of Genesis. Can I tell you that we must prioritize our time with God? And we must guard our time with God. As we think about Abraham here in calling on the name of the Lord and prioritizing his worship of God, I believe that in our lives today that it's not sufficient enough for us to just kind of haphazardly try to have a time with God. If we don't purpose to spend time with God, it's just not gonna happen. There are way too many things to do and way too many things that are pulling for your attention that it's just going to. by chance, happen that you're going to spend time with God. You've got a purpose to do it. You have to prioritize to do it. And there may be things that you have to cut out. There may be things that you say, you know what? I'm not going to be able to tend to that today because I need to have my time with God today. There are things in which people have prioritized in their lives and there are things in which people, depending on what their, maybe their profession or what their desires, their dreams and aspirations are, that they will prioritize certain things and they will allow nothing to interfere with that thing because they've set a particular goal. And I just wonder, as the people of God, do we have that same perspective with regard to our priority of our time with God? Listen, something better be burning down to interrupt my time with God. Seriously, it has to be a priority. It has to be a priority. Because as we spend time with God, as we have that walk with God, that's when somebody's going to say, God is with thee. I see that it's real. Why? Because it is real. Because I have spent time with God. Do you ever wonder about the disciples in Acts chapter number four? There's a great miracle that takes place in Acts chapter number three. Peter and John are going into the temple and the man that's lame is laying there and he's asking for money. He's asking for alms. And Peter looks at him and says, look over here, and I think the man had every expectation that he was going to get some type of monetary gift. And then those words come out of Peter's mouth, silver and gold have I none. What disappointment that man might have had in that moment. Why? Because that's what he was looking for. But such as I have, give I thee in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk. He got a whole lot more than he was looking for. Amen? And the Bible tells us that he gets up, man, he's leaping and praising God. He goes into the temple. It's amazing what happens. You come to Acts chapter number four. And there's a big stir and a big controversy. Because the religious leaders of the day, the Sadducees and the Pharisees and the Sanhedrin, they don't like what's taking place. They don't like all these people getting saved and all these things happening. And they're not profiting the way they'd like to profit. And they call these men into question. Peter stands and he says, if we be questioned on this day of the miracle that took place. And he goes through and he says, look, it's not in our power, it's not in my name. It's in the name of Jesus. And he says this, and there's no other name under heaven given among men whereby ye must be saved. The boldness. They didn't like it. If you read the very next verse, I believe it's Acts 4.13, it says that they perceived that they were ignorant and unlearned men. But that they had been with Jesus. Is that what it says? I closed my Bible, that's what it says, right? They perceived they were ignorant and unlearned men, but they had been with Jesus. Does anyone know that we've been with Jesus? Seriously. You look at Abraham and Abimelech says, God is with thee in all that thou doest. Therefore, I need to make a covenant with you. I need to have a peace treaty. And we see at the end of the passage, the priority of Abraham that is the key to the observation that is made in the beginning of our text this evening. Why is it that Abimelech perceived? Why is it that he observed that God is with thee in all that thou doest? Because Abraham made a priority to worship God. And when we make a priority to worship God, when we spend time with Jesus, when we take and we protect that time, when we say nothing's gonna interrupt this time, I'm going to spend time with God, it's gonna make a difference. And people will perceive you've been with Jesus. And God works, and God does amazing things. Because we've spent time with him, we've worshiped him. What a great observation of Abimelech. But it didn't happen by some kind of random chance. There's a priority of Abraham. Let's pray. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. We'd say, as John the Baptist said, he must increase, I must decrease. Would you help us, Lord, to exalt and magnify you in our lives? Well, thank you for the work that you'll do. For it's in Christ's name we pray. Would you stand with me?
